By understanding their strengths and weaknesses, designers can create interfaces that are effective, user-friendly, and even evoke positive emotions.

casts.text:
Recall vs. Recognition

Two of the most important factors that shape effective and intuitive interfaces.

Recall: This refers to the ability to retrieve information from memory without any external cues. Think of it as remembering your phone number without looking at your contact list.

casts.text:
Why I Still Wireframe and Encourage the Culture

-

Users crave effortless access to information to fulfil their goal.

Where is biggest BTC buy order?

What is the affordable route to bridge ETH to Base?

What is the price impact if I swap 10 SOL to a meme token?

casts.text:
Emotional design is all about humanizing products where users can connect and reminisce about real-world moments.

Like the Duolingo owl cheering you on or Airbnb illustrations evoking travel dreams, design can spark positive emotions & memories.

🧵 1/2

bio.text:
Maker on the web since the dot-com bubble. 

Interaction designer building bridges between humans, technology and business. 

This is my journal.

childCast.text:
Even colors and words matter too! Carefully chosen language and pallete builds trust & connection.

Such emotional bonds drive joyful experience and a long-lasting relation with the product as well as the brand.

What product design has most resonated with you emotionally?

🧵 2/2

casts.text:
How do you approach (if at all) setting aside crypto for your children?

I’ve been considering setting a side a certain amount of ETH & BTC for my son to get when he turns 18. More fun than serious.

Hardware wallets won’t last long enough. Paper won’t either. 

Have you done this? If so, how?

casts.text:
Unearthed a 2013 gem - my "Designyana," the mindset guide I created that prepares me for any design project. Stuck? Review it for inspiration! 

This paper shaped me! Time for a reprint & a renewed reminder.

casts.text:
I find myself being more creative when designing using HTML/CSS/React than Figma. Even the final result is way better than my best Figma mockup.

Is anyone else experiencing this? It’s a bit weird.

bio.text: Founder of Readnet • Building https://Watchen.xyz •  https://tazes.me • Crypto, tech, finance

childCast.text: For my personal projects, yes. First I make the paper-pencil sketch, and then hop into code. Plus, I utilize my own design system.

casts.text:
How I gain buy-in from stakeholders?

Show, don't tell.

Use the power of visual communication. Load designs onto a device and let them interact.

This mindset was inspired by my time as a developer, where I learned from Linus Torvalds' quote: "Talk is cheap, show me the code".

casts.text:
I’m trying to redesign one of the sore spots of an item picker in our vision OS app. Can anyone share any good examples of item selectors, especially in video games? The first thing that comes to mind is the analog selectors to choose your character in GTA V.

Any ideas?

childCast.text:

Not sure how practical it will be because of usage right, but I encourage you to experiment.

Hope my thoughts help!

casts.text:
Today I designed the cover of my newsletter weekly series - hidden gems - with my friend @datzel 

The goal was to find a flexible design that maintained the style of my publication. 

The hidden gems is a weekly curation of art, products, and blockchain content.

We settled for this (a new gem every week) 

Thoughts?

Let's expand our focus!

casts.text:
Think data as building blocks.

Each block is an "entity" with specific "attributes" (like a product with its name, price, etc.). Then a mapping to showing how these blocks are relate to each other.

It's all about making complex data feel natural & engaging!

2/3

childCast.text:
Often designers get confused with data modelling with information architecture. They are not same, but you can draw similarities.

There are lot of literature around data modelling. Starting with the basics can make a huge difference. Dive in!

If you have any questions or want to know more hit the reply

3/3

- Call to Action: Simplify by having one primary action button, secondary actions can be presented as less prominent text links below.
- Banner: Reduce the prominence of the DevShop banner. Consider replacing it with a text-based link for a lesser distraction
- Brand Color: ref Screen 1

casts.text:
Screen 3:

- Button Styles: Instead of disabling the external wallet button, use your secondary button style for it and your primary style for the Magic Wallet button. This provides clearer visual distinction.
- Title: Change "Mint to" to "Claim to" for consistency with the action initiated via the claim button.

casts.text:
Screen 2:

- Flow: Swap screens 2 and 3 to first ask about the preferred claim method (external wallet or Magic Wallet). This allows skipping email authentication for external wallets.
- Email Authentication: Avoid auto-signing in without user consent. Emphasize and obtain explicit approval before proceeding.

casts.text:
Screen 1:

- Title: Add NFT title (Proof of Cocoa) to maintain context from the notification.
- Emphasis: Downplay the greeting and emphasize the NFT title to prioritize the content.
- Brand Color: Excessive use of brand color can be overwhelming. Use it sparingly on significant elements to maintain brand identity.

casts.text:
Good designers are ego-dead.

They are detached from their work in a way that they can throw stuff away liberally without feeling bad about it.

bio.text:
Maker on the web since the dot-com bubble. 

Interaction designer building bridges between humans, technology and business. 

This is my journal.

casts.text:
Design and art—are they the same?

In my opinion, they are not.

Design always comes with a briefing or a statement, whereas art doesn't need to have one.

Art is free-flowing by its nature; it can be a reflection or an emotional feeling, and it's subjective to the viewer.

bio.text:
Maker on the web since the dot-com bubble. 

Interaction designer building bridges between humans, technology and business. 

This is my journal.

childCast.text:
You can tape a banana to a wall and call it art. Or, put a dot on a big canvas and call it art.

On the other hand, design is a systematic solution for the masses, like being able to book a taxi with one tap or keep your journal in order.

wdyt, are design and art the same?

casts.text: Designcasters - rate the new AirGraph landing page

bio.text: ceo @ AirGraph

childCast.text:
For minimal tone, play with copy & font hierarchy for emphasis. Try font pairing. For copy ideas, use AI prompts, but keep it concise & natural.

Increase spacing & adjust font in navbar for clarity and balance the white space. Also, use color accents to distinguish state and keep link labels short & intuitive.

bio.text:
Maker on the web since the dot-com bubble. 

Interaction designer building bridges between humans, technology and business. 

This is my journal.
ceo @ AirGraph

casts.text: Apple Vision Pro got me thinking... could VR & AI render loneliness obsolete? Imagine an empty room, transformed into a vibrant social hub with virtual loved ones. Physical solitude wouldn't equate to emotional isolation anymore.

bio.text:
Maker on the web since the dot-com bubble.

This is my journal.
